title: What are some alternatives to statistical significance testing? - Quora

response.answer_text: You can use Bayesian methods (instead of frequentist hypothesis testing) to find the distribution of the unknown parameters. Instead of trying to reject the notion that [math]\mu = 0[/math], you can actually construct a distribution for mu if you're willing to subscribe to Bayesian ideology and say that an unknown parameter can have a distribution that reflects one's uncertainty about the value.   For example, lets say that you're trying to estimate the probability parameter [math]\theta[/math] of a binomial distribution (say, click-through rate). You set an initial flat prior for [math]\theta[/math] to be[math]\theta \sim Beta(1, 1)[/math] Through Baye's Rule, you get your posterior distribution for [math]\theta[/math] to be[math]P(\theta | data) \propto P(data | \theta)P(\theta)[/math]. Conveniently in this case, the distribution [math]\theta | data \sim Beta(1 + y, 1 + n)[/math] Where y is the number of observed successes (e.g. clicks) and n is the number of trials (e.g. impressions).   I've illustrated three Beta distributions below to illustrate what has happened. We start off with a Beta(1, 1), or flat, prior for our belief of the distribution of [math]\theta[/math].  After observing 1 click in 4 impressions, we can update our belief of of the distribution of [math]\theta[/math] to be Beta(2, 5). From the posterior distribution we can make judgements about what [math]\theta[/math] is likely to be.    EDIT: If you're looking for a Bayesian alternative to hypothesis testing, check out the Bayes factor

You can look at all of statistics as a part of a principled argument (as in Robert Abelson's excellent book Statistics As Principled Argument: Robert P. Abelson: 9780805805284: Amazon.com: Books. I reviewed this book on my site Page on statisticalanalysisconsulting.com but, briefly, use the MAGIC criteria: Magnitude - how big is the effect?Articulation - how precisely is it stated?Generatlity - to how big a group does it apply?Interestingness - how interesting is it?Credibility - how believable is it?
